bibl.title: Despatch from M. A. Aenmey to John Hay
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p:
U.S. Vice Consulate General.
Monrovia, July 1e 1880

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your dispatch No 13, addressed to the Consul General J. H Smyth Esqre the dispatch to the U.S. Consular officer at Monrovia, dated February 24th and Cicular No. 18 with accompanying Table of Estimate of Values of Foreign Coins.

In referrence to aforesaid dispatch No. 13; I beg must respectfully to inform the department that, the Hon J. H Smyth left on the 8th day of May ulto for Sierra Leone and the U.S. of America, with leave of absence.

In regard to the dispatch dated Febry 24th 1880, I regret greatly that the office at Monrovia is among the delinquents in some of the Catagories to which the dispatch
Hon John Hay
Asst Secretary of State
Washington D.C.
dispatch refers, and I feel sorry to inform the department that it is literally impossible, to furnish the "National Board of Health" with the regular weekly reports required.
The death in this Republic are never recorded by any Governments or local authority, and at least 50% of the deceased, die without calling for medical assistence.

The Medical Faculty, the only source from which such imformations, as required, can be obtained, is unable, under the present circumstances, to control the same or to furnish regular reports, except, if a private physician was salaried, special for that purpose.

More than ¾ of the cities or settlements in Liberia, are without physicians and even where a physician is situated, the power classes of the people are usually attended
attended by so called Country Doctors, who are an uneducated, half civilized class of men, using native plants as medicines by which in many cases death is caused sooner than by the original decease.
Notwithstanding, I shall use all my endeavours, to furnish the National Board of Health with the best imformations, as under the existing circumstances can be obtained.
As regards the Consulate at Cape Coast Castle, I beg to refer to the dispatch of the Honl J. H. Smyth to the department No 47 dated February 2e 1880.

I have the honor to be Sir
Your obedt Servt
M. A. Aenmey
